newsitem.title: INDONESIA: June start seen for $2.2 billion Indonesia subway.
newsitem.headline: June start seen for $2.2 billion Indonesia subway.

text.p: Indonesia will soon start building a $2.2 billion subway linking two business districts in an effort to end crippling traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta, the official Antara news agency reported on Thursday.

The agency quoted businessman Aburizal Bakrie, who heads a consortium of Indonesian, Japanese and European companies, as saying on Wednesday the construction of the 14.5-km (nine mile) subway would start in June.
The subway which links Blok M in south Jakarta and the historic Kota area in the north is expected to be completed by August 17, 2001 to coincide with the country's 56th anniversary of independence.
Bustling Jakarta is home to nearly 10 million people and already faces chronic traffic jams, especially in the morning and afternoon peak hours.
Bakrie said the government had given the investors approval to use private loans to fund the project, adding that a number of foreign countries had also agreed to fund the project.
"Informally, they have given their agreement," Bakrie said without elaborating.

The Jakarta Post newspaper reported on Thursday the city administration had initially planned to raise $25 million per year for five years as its equity in the project, and another $35 million a year for 25 years to pay back loans. It gave no further details.
A conglomerate controlled by President Suharto's eldest daughter Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana will also start building a $2.45 billion road-rail link in Jakarta in April.

PT Citra Lamtoro Gung Persada will construct the multi-deck structure which consists of a 23.55 km (14.7 mile) toll road, a 21.25 km (13.2 mile) railway and a public road to link south Jakarta with downtown Kota in the north.
The flyover is due to start operations in 2001.
